<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[632, 220, 722, 236]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[736, 213, 905, 261]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[891, 278, 905, 294]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[783, 302, 905, 316]]<|/det|> May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[851, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 361, 399]]<|/det|> No additional materials are needed. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 291, 450]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 449, 761, 466]]<|/det|> - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 464, 808, 481]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 480, 565, 497]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 478, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 528]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 550, 545]]<|/det|> - You should use a scientific calculator where appropriate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 460, 560]]<|/det|> - You must show all necessary working clearly. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 559, 856, 576]]<|/det|> - Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 589, 485, 604]]<|/det|> - For \(\pi\), use either your calculator value or 3.142. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 214, 647]]<|/det|> INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 649, 388, 665]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 80 . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 665, 730, 682]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 74, 567, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 105, 477, 124]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[601, 103, 786, 126]]<|/det|>
\[
(x-a)^{2}+(y-b)^{2}=r^{2}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 157, 537, 174]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[604, 157, 678, 173]]<|/det|>
\[
A=\pi r l
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 205, 372, 220]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[604, 201, 686, 220]]<|/det|>
\[
A=4 \pi r^{2}
\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[603, 246, 680, 275]]<|/det|>
\[
V=\frac{1}{3} A h
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 251, 496, 269]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[603, 290, 686, 321]]<|/det|>
\[
V=\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 300, 336, 317]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 349, 234, 364]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 345, 656, 364]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2}+b x+c=0\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 367, 559, 404]]<|/det|>
\[
x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 449, 225, 464]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 437, 907, 526]]<|/det|>
\[
(a+b)^{n}=a^{n}+\binom{n}{1} a^{n-1} b+\binom{n}{2} a^{n-2} b^{2}+\ldots+\binom{n}{r} a^{n-r} b^{r}+\ldots+b^{n},
\quad \text { where } n \text { is a positive integer and } \binom{n}{r}=\frac{n !}{(n-r) ! r !}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 554, 217, 569]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 552, 669, 599]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& u_{n}=a+(n-1) d \\
& S_{n}=\frac{1}{2} n(a+l)=\frac{1}{2} n\{2 a+(n-1) d\}
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 632, 217, 647]]<|/det|>
Geometric series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 628, 573, 710]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& u_{n}=a r^{n-1} \\
& S_{n}=\frac{a(1-r^{n})}{1-r} \quad(r \neq 1) \\
& S_{\infty}=\frac{a}{1-r} \quad(|r|<1)
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 741, 157, 754]]<|/det|>
Identities

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 736, 556, 790]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \sin ^{2} A+\cos ^{2} A=1 \\
& \sec ^{2} A=1+\tan ^{2} A \\
& \operatorname{cosec}^{2} A=1+\cot ^{2} A
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 829, 239, 844]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta A B C\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 823, 576, 901]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{a}{\sin A}=\frac{b}{\sin B}=\frac{c}{\sin C} \\
& a^{2}=b^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c \cos A \\
& \Delta=\frac{1}{2} a b \sin C
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 443, 93]]<|/det|>
1 Solve the inequality \((x+2)(4 x-5) \leqslant 0\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 248, 675, 286]]<|/det|>
2 Given that \(y=\frac{4 x^{3}-5}{x^{2}}\) ，show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}\) can be written as \(\frac{2\left(2 x^{3}+5\right)}{x^{3}}\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 583, 918, 602]]<|/det|>
3 Variables \(x\) and \(y\) are such that when \(\sqrt{y}\) is plotted against \(x^{3}\) a straight line graph passing through the points \((2,5)\) and \((10,21)\) is obtained．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 630, 277, 647]]<|/det|>
Find \(y\) in terms of \(x\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 548, 92]]<|/det|>
4 The function f is defined by \(\mathrm{f}(x)=2 x-1\) for \(x \in \mathbb{R}\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 501, 124]]<|/det|>
（a）Explain why the function \(\mathrm{f}^{2}\) can be formed．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 243, 515, 263]]<|/det|>
（b）On the axes，sketch the graph of \(y=\left|\mathrm{f}^{2}(x)\right|\) ． State any intercepts with the coordinate axes．

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 292, 704, 579]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 693, 769, 714]]<|/det|>
（c）It is given that \(\left|\mathrm{f}^{2}(x)\right| \leqslant a x+b\) for \(-1 \leqslant x \leqslant 3\) and for no other values of \(x\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 728, 366, 743]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 438, 91]]<|/det|>
5 In this question，all angles are in radians．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 97, 457, 128]]<|/det|>
（a）Write down the period of \(5 \tan \left(\frac{x}{4}\right)+1\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 267, 708, 298]]<|/det|>
（b）On the axes，sketch the graph of \(y=5 \tan \left(\frac{x}{4}\right)+1\) for \(-2 \pi \leqslant x \leqslant 4 \pi\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 306, 424, 323]]<|/det|>
State the intercept with the \(y\)－axis． Show clearly the positions of any asymptotes．

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 353, 799, 659]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 744, 91]]<|/det|>
6 (a) Five of the digits 123456789 are used to make a 5-digit number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 105, 825, 122]]<|/det|>
Find how many ways this can be done when the 5 -digit number is greater than 50000 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 306, 648, 323]]<|/det|>
(b) In a group of 13 people, 7 have red hair and 6 have brown hair.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 337, 547, 352]]<|/det|>
(i) The 13 people stand in line for a photograph. No person with red hair is standing next to another person with red hair.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 382, 598, 399]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways this can be done.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 583, 507, 600]]<|/det|>
(ii) Chris chooses 5 people from this group.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 614, 854, 629]]<|/det|>
Find the number of ways Chris can do this if at least 1 person chosen has brown hair.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 657, 114]]<|/det|>
7 (a) Find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(x^{2}-\frac{3}{x^{4}}\right)^{15}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 299, 811, 319]]<|/det|>
(b) In the expansion of \((1+a x)^{9}\) the coefficient of \(x^{3}\) is 7 times the coefficient of \(x^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 333, 579, 350]]<|/det|>
Given that \(a\) is a positive constant, find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 406, 97]]<|/det|>
8 (a) It is given that \(y=\mathrm{e}^{3 x+2} \tan x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 109, 918, 126]]<|/det|>
Use calculus to find the approximate change in \(y\) as \(x\) increases from 0.1 to \(0.1+h\), where \(h\) is small.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 454, 107]]<|/det|>
(b) A curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}=\sin (3 x+\pi)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 121, 490, 157]]<|/det|>
The curve passes through the point \(\left(\frac{\pi}{9}, \frac{4}{3}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 172, 688, 199]]<|/det|>
Find the exact \(y\)-coordinate of the point on the curve where \(x=\frac{5 \pi}{12}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 518, 91]]<|/det|>
9 (a) The 1st term of an arithmetic progression is 9. The last term of this progression is 159 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 105, 416, 120]]<|/det|>
The sum of all the terms is 2604 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 136, 832, 152]]<|/det|>
The 12th term of this arithmetic progression is the 1st term of a geometric progression. The 8th term of this arithmetic progression is the 2nd term of the geometric progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 181, 642, 198]]<|/det|>
Find the sum of the first 6 terms of the geometric progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 567, 92]]<|/det|>
(b) A different geometric progression has 1st term \(\sin \theta\). The common ratio of this progression is \(\cos \theta\) where \(45^{\circ} \leqslant \theta \leqslant 135^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 121, 570, 138]]<|/det|>
(i) Show that this progression has a sum to infinity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[152, 290, 695, 307]]<|/det|>
(ii) Show that this sum to infinity can be written as \(\operatorname{cosec} \theta+\cot \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 74, 393, 91]]<|/det|>
10 In this question, time is in seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 716, 122]]<|/det|>
(a) At time \(t=0\), particle \(P\) starts from the point with position vector \(-30 \mathbf{j}\). \(P\) travels with speed \(58 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) in the direction \(20 \mathbf{i}+21 \mathbf{j}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 152, 454, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the position vector of \(P\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 396, 802, 415]]<|/det|>
(b) Also at time \(t=0\), particle \(Q\) starts from the point with position vector \(-10 \mathbf{i}+18 \mathbf{j}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 423, 840, 450]]<|/det|>
\(Q\) travels with speed \(75 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) at an angle \(\alpha\) above the positive \(x\)-axis, where \(\tan \alpha=\frac{7}{24}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 460, 457, 477]]<|/det|>
Find the position vector of \(Q\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 74, 439, 91]]<|/det|>
(c) Determine whether \(P\) and \(Q\) collide.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 322, 692, 358]]<|/det|>
11 Given that \(\frac{{ }^{n+1} \mathrm{P}_{5}}{437}={ }^{n} \mathrm{P}_{3}\), use an algebraic method to find the value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 76, 918, 96]]<|/det|>
12 The function f is defined by \(\mathrm{f}(x)=15 \cos ^{2}(3 x+1.5)+7 \sin (3 x+1.5)-13\) for \(-0.3 \leqslant x \leqslant 0.5\), where \(x\) is in radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 125, 380, 142]]<|/det|>
(a) Solve the equation \(\mathrm{f}(x)=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 76, 736, 93]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the \(x\)-coordinates of the two stationary points on the curve \(y=\mathrm{f}(x)\).
